policy_name: AB 540 - In-State Tuition for Undocumented Students
eligibility: Attended CA high school for 3+ years AND graduated from CA high school (or equivalent) AND filed affidavit stating will apply for legal status when eligible
documentation_required: CA high school diploma or equivalent
tuition_benefit: In-state tuition at UC/CSU/CCC (saves ~$30k/year at UC)
notes: Does NOT require DACA or legal status. Applies to undocumented, DACA, and even international students who meet the 3-year CA HS requirement.

policy_name: CA Dream Act (State Financial Aid for AB 540 Students)
eligibility: Meet AB 540 requirements AND demonstrate financial need
documentation_required: CADAA (CA Dream Act Application) instead of FAFSA
federal_aid_notes: Undocumented and DACA students are NOT eligible for federal aid (Pell Grant, federal loans, federal work-study)
application: CADAA (CA Dream Act Application) - similar to FAFSA but for AB 540 students
max_aid_amount: Up to full tuition + living expenses (same as citizens for state aid)
notes: CA is one of few states offering state aid to undocumented students. CADAA uses 000-00-0000 for parent SSN if parents don't have SSN.

policy_name: HB 1403 - In-State Tuition for Undocumented Students
eligibility: Resided in TX for 3+ years AND graduated from TX high school (or GED) AND filed affidavit
documentation_required: TX high school diploma or GED
tuition_benefit: In-state tuition at TX public colleges
state_aid_notes: Eligible for TX state aid (TEXAS Grant, etc.) as of 2021
notes: TX was first state to offer in-state tuition to undocumented students. State aid eligibility added in 2021.

description: Federal program providing temporary protection from deportation and work authorization
eligibility: Entered U.S. before age 16, continuously resided in U.S. since June 15, 2007, under age 31 as of June 15, 2012, in school or graduated or veteran, no serious criminal record
application_process: File Form I-821D with USCIS + $495 fee
renewal_process: Renew every 2 years (120-150 days before expiration)
current_status: Active but subject to legal challenges; no new applications accepted (as of 2025, only renewals)
financial_aid_impact: DACA students are NOT eligible for federal aid (FAFSA) but may be eligible for state aid (CA, TX, NY, etc.) and private college aid
work_authorization: Can work legally with EAD; eligible for internships, CPT (at some schools), but NOT eligible for OPT or H-1B sponsorship

description: Temporary immigration status for nationals of designated countries facing armed conflict, natural disaster, or other extraordinary conditions
financial_aid_impact: TPS holders are NOT eligible for federal aid. Dependents of TPS holders (even if U.S. born) may face complications with FAFSA if parents don't have SSN.

description: How to complete CSS Profile when parents don't have Social Security Numbers
process: Enter 000-00-0000 for parent SSN on CSS Profile
documentation: May need to provide alternative documentation (ITIN, foreign tax returns, income statements)
impact_on_aid: Does not affect aid eligibility at schools that offer aid to undocumented/DACA students
schools_requiring_ssn: Some schools may require SSN for aid; check individual school policies
notes: CSS Profile allows 000-00-0000 for parents without SSN. FAFSA does NOT allow this (FAFSA requires valid SSN for parents, which is why undocumented students can't file FAFSA).

policy: DACA Work Authorization and Career Implications
description: Work authorization limitations for DACA students after graduation
work_authorization: DACA provides EAD (Employment Authorization Document) renewable every 2 years
opt_notes: DACA students are NOT eligible for OPT (Optional Practical Training) because OPT requires F-1 visa status
h1b_notes: DACA students cannot get H-1B visa sponsorship (H-1B requires lawful status)
career_limitations: Cannot work in jobs requiring citizenship
Limited to jobs that accept EAD
professional_school_implications: Medical school: Cannot get federal loans (must pay out-of-pocket or private loans). Law school: Can practice law in some states (CA, NY, FL allow DACA lawyers). Cannot take federal clerkships.
renewal_risk: DACA is temporary and subject to policy changes. Renewal is not guaranteed.

description: Challenges and opportunities for DACA students pursuing medical school
federal_loans_notes: DACA students cannot get federal loans (Direct Unsubsidized, Grad PLUS). Must pay out-of-pocket or private loans.
residency_training: Can complete residency training with EAD (work authorization)
medical_license: Can obtain medical license in most states with DACA status
state_restrictions: Some states may restrict medical licenses for non-citizens (check state medical board)
cost_implications: Medical school costs $200k-$400k. Without federal loans, DACA students need private loans (higher interest) or family support.
schools_offering_aid: Very few medical schools offer institutional aid to DACA students. Check individual school policies.
